abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First Phase of
            Programmatic Fiscal Sustainability Development Policy Loan
            Project for Iraq were as follows: outcomes was moderately
            satisfactory, risk to development outcome was substantial,
            Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: This operation confirmed the importance of
            linking the Development Policy Lending with (a) solid
            analytical work and (b) with investment and technical
            assistance operations, especially in the fragile environment
            applicable in Iraq. Both applied in this case, and have been
            a key requirement for the relative success of this
            operation. The conflict situation and fragile policy
            environment in Iraq makes almost any operation a high risk
            operation in terms of achieving its outcomes. This operation
            assumed risks, especially fiduciary risks but also
            substantial, program‖ risks. It has been important to assume
            these risks to achieve the progress made, even if this
            judgment will be contentious. As the Lesson Learned section
            of the project document states (paragraph 131), risks
            should, however be mitigated. A proper analysis of risk
            mitigation options is important and could lead in the
            process to possible adjustments of the overall operations,
            making the overall undertaking more successful, as risks and
            risks mitigation strategies or options would have been
            clarified. There is a need to be realistic in countries
            facing conflict and a fragile situation like in Iraq. The
            encompassing procurement and the social safety net reform
            envisaged by this operation within more or less one year
            would have been very ambitious under normal circumstances.
            Realism would need to be translated into a more step-by-step
            reform approach, a more gradual or incremental reform
            process, which by itself could also lead to the definition
            of more precise (and realistic) outcome indicators. This
            seems also to be in line with the lessons learned as
            expressed in the project document. Another way to become
            more realistic in situations like the one in Iraq would be
            to make more active use of political economy analysis
            especially concerning the largest reform elements. Politics
            is always dominant in fragile situations and institutions,
            by definition, underperform. It is therefore not only
            important to know what constitutes good or better policies
            in a given situation, but it is also important to know about
            what range of reform is feasible in a given time period, and
            how the incentives for reform are distributed. This would
            positively impact the risk assessment as well as inform the
            operation‘s design. It must have been difficult to monitor
            or supervise this operation in the given Iraqi environment
            where a proper monitoring environment does not yet exist,
            and collaboration across institutions is difficult, among
            others because of the fragmented political situation. In
            such a situation more reliance is then on the operation‘s
            own monitoring framework and its design. It is therefore
            recommended to critically assess the monitoring framework
            and outcome indicators as well as the monitoring design for
            future operations in light of the weak country system. It
            would also have been recommendable to agree on a verifiable
            monitoring arrangement for the main implementation agency.
